content: The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 is cited as the constitutional authority to regulate commerce and make laws necessary for executing government powers. This Act addresses identity theft. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 amends Section 1028(a) of title 18, United States Code to include knowingly transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority to commit unlawful activities. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 expands penalties under Section 1028(b) of title 18, United States Code for offenses involving the transfer or use of means of identification resulting in obtaining anything of value over $1,000 in a year. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 increases penalties under Section 1028(b) of title 18, United States Code for offenses involving the transfer, use, or possession of means of identification, identification documents, or a means of identification resulting in obtaining anything of value over $1,000 in a year. Penalties include fines, imprisonment for up to 20 years, or both, especially if the offense is committed to facilitate a drug trafficking crime. Penalties include fines, imprisonment for up to 20 years, or both, especially if the offense is committed to facilitate a drug trafficking crime. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for forfeiture of any personal property used or intended to be used to commit the offense. The Act is amended to specify that the prohibited actions must be related to interstate or foreign commerce, or involve transportation of identification materials through the mail. The United States Code is amended to define terms related to document-making implements and identification documents, specifying their meanings and uses. The term 'means of identification' refers to any name or number that can be used to identify an individual, including social security numbers, dates of birth, driver's license numbers, passport numbers, and employer or taxpayer identification numbers. The term 'personal identification card' refers to an ID issued by a government for identification purposes, and 'produce' includes altering, authenticating, or assembling. The term 'produce' in the context of personal identification cards includes altering, authenticating, or assembling. Additionally, any person who attempts or conspires to commit an offense related to personal identification cards will face the same penalties as those prescribed for the actual offense. The forfeiture procedures for property related to offenses involving personal identification cards are governed by specific laws. Additionally, a rule of construction is established for interpreting subsection (a)(7) of the code. The rule of construction under subsection (a)(7) states that a single identification document with multiple means of identification will be considered as one means of identification. Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include "and information" in the heading and table of sections for section 1028. SEC. 4. AMENDMENT OF FEDERAL SENTENCING GUIDELINES FOR OFFENSES UNDER SECTION 1028. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to establish appropriate penalties for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors such as the number of victims involved will be considered during this process. The value of harm caused by the offense, number of identification documents involved, and extent of loss to individuals are key factors for determining penalties under Federal sentencing guidelines. The factors considered for establishing penalties under Federal sentencing guidelines include the range of conduct covered by the offense, sentencing enhancements, statutory maximum penalties, and ensuring punishment for the most egregious conduct. The factors for establishing penalties under Federal sentencing guidelines include the range of conduct covered by the offense, sentencing enhancements, statutory maximum penalties, and other relevant factors considered by the United States Sentencing Commission. SEC. 5. CENTRALIZED COMPLAINT AND CONSUMER EDUCATION SERVICE FOR VICTIMS OF IDENTITY THEFT. The Federal Trade Commission will establish procedures within a year of this Act's enactment to log complaints, provide information, and refer cases of identity theft violations to appropriate authorities. The Federal Trade Commission will establish procedures to log complaints and refer cases of identity theft violations to national consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement agencies for potential action. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. Technical amendments to Title 18, United States Code are outlined in Section 6. Technical amendments to Title 18, United States Code include changes related to criminal forfeiture procedures and the inclusion of economic espionage and theft of trade secrets as predicate offenses for wire interception. The Title 18, United States Code is amended to include "chapter 90 (protection of trade secrets)" after "espionage)." SEC. 7. REDACTION OF ETHICS REPORTS FILED BY JUDICIAL OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES. Section 105(b) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to allow for redaction of reports filed by certain individuals if revealing personal information could endanger them. Redactions are only permitted to protect the individual and as long as the danger exists. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts must submit an annual report to Congress regarding the redaction of reports filed by individuals to protect them from danger. The report should include the total number of redacted reports, individuals affected, and types of threats faced. The Judicial Conference, in consultation with the Department of Justice, will issue regulations for redaction circumstances and procedures. This provision expires on December 31, 2001, and applies to filings through that year.
